FIHR 0.1.0
  • Reference

Inference for linear functional in the high-dimensional logistic regression model

LF_Inference_logistic.Rd

Computes the bias corrected estimator of the linear functional for the high-dimensional logistic regression model and the corresponding standard error.

LF_Inference_logistic(
  X,
  y,
  loading,
  weight,
  lambda = NULL,
  intercept = FALSE,
  mu = NULL,
  step = NULL,
  resol = 1.5,
  maxiter = 6
)

Arguments

X

Design matrix
y

Response vector
loading

observation vector in the linear functional
weight

The vector of weights used in correcting the plug-in estimator
lambda

Tuning parameter in construction of the LASSO estimator of the regression vector (default = NULL)
intercept

Should intercept(s) be fitted (default = FALSE)
mu

Tuning parameter in construction of the projection direction (default = NULL)
step

Number of steps (< maxiter) to obtain the smallest mu that gives convergence of the optimization problem for constructing the projection direction (default = NULL)
resol

Resolution or the factor by which mu is increased/decreased to obtain the smallest mu that gives convergence of the optimization problem for constructing the projection direction (default = 1.5)
maxiter

Maximum number of steps along which mu is increased/decreased to obtain the smallest mu that gives convergence of the optimization problem for constructing the projection direction (default = 6)

Value

prop.est

The bias corrected estimator of the linear functional

se

Standard error of the bias-corrected estimator

proj

Optimal projection direction

step

Number of steps (< maxiter) to obtain the smallest mu that gives convergence of the optimization problem for constructing the projection direction

plug.in

Plug-in LASSO estimator of the linear functional

support

Estimated support for the regression vector (using LASSO estimate)

References

Guo Z, Rakshit P, Herman DS, Chen J (2019). “Inference for Case Probability in High-dimensional Logistic Regression.” Unknown.

Examples

LF_Inference_logistic(X = matrix(sample(-2:2,50*300,replace = TRUE),nrow=50,ncol=300),
                      y = rbinom(50,1,0.5), loading = c(1,rep(0,299)),
                      intercept = TRUE, weight = rep(1,50))
#> [1] 2
#> [1] "step is 2"
#> $prop.est
#> [1] 0.7006761

#> [1] 0.2662161
